newsitem.title: BELGIUM: SGB willing to give up control of non-core stakes.
newsitem.headline: SGB willing to give up control of non-core stakes.

text.p: Belgian holding company Societe Generale de Belgique SA (SGB) is willing to give up control of its non-strategic assets, SGB chairman Etienne Davignon said in a newspaper interview on Saturday.

"Even though all SGB's assets, with the exception of (utility holding company) Tractebel, are no longer strategic, SGB will keep supporting them fully...SGB is even willing to give up control of these units, if it is in their interest," Davignon was quoted as saying in Belgian financial daily De Financieel-Economische Tijd.

Following the announcement of the planned merger of SGB's French parent company Compagnie de Suez with French utility group Lyonnaise des Eaux, Tractebel is now the only strategic Belgian asset in the new merged group, which wants to become a world leader in utilities services.
SGB's other key Belgian stakes include Generale Bank, insurer Fortis AG and non-ferrous metals group Union Miniere SA (UM).

"If Suez would still call financial assets such as Generale Bank, Fortis and Sofinco strategic, then the outside world would have seen the merger purely as a reshuffle of assets," said Davignon, who is also a Suez board member.

The FET quoted Davignon as saying that SGB no longer insists on keeping its 30 percent controlling stake in Generale Bank, and that it no longer has a problem with the idea of Internationale Nederlanden Groep (ING) as a shareholder in a future merged Belgian bank.

Year-old plans to merge Generale Bank with Belgian holding company Groupe Bruxelles Lambert SA (GBL) had been blocked by disagreement between ING -- which controls 20 percent of BBL voting stock -- and Belgian bank shareholders over the role of ING in a future merged bank.
